"The present plan (six weeks'
rushing of freshmen at the beginning of their first semester of
school) has a good chance of remaining somewhat intact," said
Inter-Fraternity Board president
13ill Kolomaznik.
"The trend is toward keeping
the status quo, and finding something that'is satisfactory to all.
Now it is not a question of needing change; the problem is to get
a compromise that represents a
change," he said in evaluation of

publication
We suspend
With this issue in order to bid
our professors a brief hail and
farewell this semester. We
hope to return on Friday, February 15.

the four week discussion of
changing the rush season's time
and length that has been going
on in the IFB.
• At the IFB's meeting last week,
Phi Alpha was made a member
by unanimous vote of all members. Phi Alpha has taken no
stand on rush changes or the
possibility of abolishing drinking
during rushing, which is also being considered by the IFB.•
"The general feeling among
some fraternity men was that the
rush season should be changed.
Dean Shaffer (Dean of the Homewood Schools) also spoke to us
at the beginning of the year and
made a big point that every year
for the past several years he had
encouraged the IFB to change it.
This year he said he would possibly change it if we didn't, that

we were flunking boys out of
school, and that the problem of
drinking does the most harm in
the general orientation of freshmen. He said we should think of
rushing in regards to the orientation of freshmen as well as from
our own interests in it," Kolomaznik said in explaining why the
changes were suggested.
Although changes were recommended from two sources, the
trend seems toward maintaining
the status quo.
With the exception of DU and
KA, who were unavailable for
comment, fraternity presidents
took the following stands on
changing the rush season and the
possibility of the IFB abolishing

DR. MILTON EISENHOWER, Hopkins Eighth President
Milton Stover Eisenhower will be installed as the
eighth president of The Johns Hopkins University on Friday, February 22 at the University's annual Commemoration Day Convocation at Shriver Hall on the Homewood
Campus.
This year's celebration will mark the 81st anniversary
of the,founding of Johns Hopkins in 1876.
A long tradition will be followed with' Dr. Eisenhower's installation. Each previous Hopkins president has
been installed at Commemoration Day ceremonies,followed
by his first major address as president. Dr. Eisenhower
will likewise deliver the featured address at this year's convocation.

CLAY

John Gassner, Sterling Professor of Playwriting at Yale University, will speak on "The Possibilities and Perils of Modern
Tragedy" in the Amos Taylor,
Jr. Lecture series sponsored by
the Johns Hopkins Playshop,
Sunday, at 8:30 in the Clipper
Room of Shriver Hall. Admission price is sixty cents, and
tickets may be reserved at the
English and Drama Department.
Mr. Gassner has been an editorial advisor for several theatre
journals a professor at Queens
College, N.Y., a critic for publications, and once headed the
script department of the Theatre
Guild of New York. He has
adapted several plays for the
stage, is a member of the Drama
Critics' Circle, and is vice-president of the Shaw Society of
London.
The Playshop's next performance will be George Bernard
Shaw's "Mr.s. Warren's Profession.' Dr. Fagin, director of the
Playshop, said this was one nf
the "most controversial and daring of the British playwright's
comedies." It will be given at
8.30 p.m. in the Barn, on February 21, 22, 23, 28 and again
on March 1 and 2. The last play
of the Playshop will be "Easter,"
by August Strindberg, on April
4, 5, 6, and 11, 12, and 13.

Claire lIruska (left) discusses progress of a new telephone building with the contractor.

- What's a civil engineer's job
in the telephone company?
Claire IIruska graduated in 1953 from
the University of Washington with a B.S.
in Civil Engineering. Today he's with
The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph
Company.
"I 'supervise construction at every
stage," Claire says. "Every telephone
building is designed around the equipment that will be in it. When a building
is needed, I work closely with the architect to make sure his plans fit the needs.
Then I check the contractors' bids. When
the contract is let, it's my responsibility

to see that the builder sticks to the plans
in detail.
"Right now I'm handling the construction of several telephone exchanges, a
large office building in downtown Seattle,
and additions to other .buildings. It's
satisfying work, because I'm on my own a
lot, and getting the jobs done is up to me.
"I've got a career that offers big assignments and responsibilities, and real
opportunities to get ahead in a business
that's growing rapidly. That's what I
was looking for."

Claire Hruska is typical of the many young men
who are finding rewarding careers in the Bell Telephone System. For more information on career
opportunities in the Bell Telephone Companies,
Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric and
Sandia Corporation, see your placement officer.

Put Him Where He Belongs
To some extent, by publishing-,the story on the charges
Senator McCarthy .directed at Dr'. Milton Eisenhower we
are doing precisely what the Senator would want us to
do—we are further publicizing his activity.
McCarthy represents the peculiar anomaly of a man
who has gained his ends largely through the offices of
those who often were bitterly opposed to his tactics. That
is, because his actions were news, they were widely publicized and as a consequence a large proportion of the
American population became McCarthy-conscious. It now
appears that McCarthy is making a feeble effort to reenter the political picture little hindered by the stigma
of senate censure. We are not suggesting that McCarthy is
staging—to borrow a Hollywood term—a comeback or
that he has any chance of ever becoming as important a
political issue as he once was.

Kidnapping:A Disillusionment?
The typical pledge's first conception of his fraternity is one
of a neat, white-shirt-and-tieand-sharp-blue-suit, party-everyweekend organization run by impeccably dressed, smiling actives
whose only purpose in life, seemingly, is to make the gasping
neophytes happy. Unfortunately,
this dream is not allowed to remain extant very long. Tests, demerits, long and dirty cleaning
jobs, endless numbers to be
memorized perfectly, and a general reversion to normal character of the actives manage to
shatter the ideals of nearly all
the pledges. But the final dis-

illusionment comes when the
room of the pledge is invaded,
the hapless pledge himself seized
and dragged to a waiting car,
and taken far, sometimes many
miles, from the city, to return
as best he can.
Most actives agree that the
general idea behind kidnapping
is to try to solidify the pledge
class by subjecting them all to
the same treatment. Another
reason given is that it helps "put
the pledges in their place," inferring that the customary "snow
job" given the pledges before
they join is all too effective. This
purpose, of giving the pledges a

Strong Opinions
Independents, though theoretically unconcerned with the
situation, have expressed strong
opinions on the subject. "How
can we overlook it, when a bunch
of guys comes busting into the
house and tearing it apart? A
lot of them don't even live on
campus;" or,"I don't really care,
since it's none of my business;
but I think it sort of upsets the
dorm." "I wish they would kidnap them quietly; I have studying to do." These were some of
the comments from Independents who ventured an opinion
about the matter. The general
consensus was that kidnapping
was upsetting to all the students
near the scene of action, though
some claimed that they were able
to successfully ignore the Phenomenon.
The pledges interviewed seemed, on the whole, to agree with
the Independents, though the
Opinions expressed were milder.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JAN. 18, 1957

PAGE NINE

Student Council President Sank Evaluates Semester;
Advising, Orientation On Agenda For Second Term
The following report is, in the
Opinion of President Lew Sank,
the present status of the Council
and a critique of the major ativities undertaken by the Council for the first semester of this
academic year.
In the past few months the
Student Council has taken great
strides in attaining its rightful
Place as the senior governing
body on the Hopkins' Campus.
Regaining much of its lost prestige, it has made serious efforts
to fulfill the objectives as stated
in the newly revised Student
Council Constitution.
In order to improve to any
great extent, however, the Council must direct criticism in two
Major areas. One area concerns
Council representatives who have
the attitude that, having once
been elected by 'popularity contest' to the Council, they no longer feel obligated to devote an
adequate amount of time and
energy to the Council.
This attitude is dissolving as
the Council takes on more work.
It should also be pointed out that
as the committee chairmen aslime more responsibility, and as

each Council member shows more
initiative, the better the status
of the Council. (To this end,
Freshmen Council members have
assigned responsibilities.)
The second, and most important, area of concern is the Council's lack of support from the
students whom they are supposed
to represent, and from the faculty and Administration as well.
Although valid, this point too
long has been depicted as a general Hopkins' trait to be argued
here. Nevertheless, if the Student
Council is to act as a responsible,
representative body, it must have
a greater amount of support from
the campus.
In my estimation, the Student
Council has at least taken those
preliminary steps to deserve increased support. In the weeks to
come, besides the present activities of the Council, I hope to investigate the advising system and
the orientation program given to
freshmen.
Intermediary Position
The Council has made greater
efforts to serve as an intermediary between Administration, faculty, and students. Letters and

special meetings between Council
representatives and administrative and faculty members have
served to represent student opinion and provide a liason between
the undergraduate body and the
Director of Student Activities, Dr.
W. Kelso Morrill; the President's
Office; the Public Relations Office; the Admissions Office; the
Registrar; the Plant Manager's
Office; and Dean Shaffer.
The Executive Committee has
met twice this semester to discuss general Council policy, and
under the direction of the Vice
President, Penn Lupovich, to direct comlnittee action with the
chairman of each permanent
committee of the Council.
Efficient Committees
The Elections Committee under
the Chairmanship of Tom Gibson has done a very efficient job
in conducting the election procedure for Freshman Officers and
for the Referendum on the revised Student Council Constitution. (In the previous two elections, the Council was faced with
contested results and, hence, had
to run re-elections.)
T h e Assembly Committee
boasts a very active program.

Bob Baensch, Chairman, has
worked hard to conduct the five
assemblies which have already
been presented. They are: (1) An
Address by President Milton S.
Eisenhower, (2) The film, "Our
Mister Sun," (3) An Address by
Richard Niebuhr co-sponsored
with the Y.M.C.A. and the Council of Religious Groups, (4) The
Annual Christmas Assembly, and
(5) The Hungarian Relief Rally,
which was also supported by
other campus organizations.
One of the most active committees this year has been the
Public Relations Committee. Paul
Gordon, the original Chairman,
has worked in close cooperation
with the Admissions office in
conducting a series of 'Introduction to College Life' programs
with many local high schools.
This committee has helped conduct the various tours of the
Hopkins campus for visitors. .
The Council has also acted as
host during the President's teas,
where it introduced faculty
guests to the receiving lines.
Tony Salem is the present chairman of the Committee.
Lupovitch Lauded
One of the biggest jobs of this
year's Council was done by Penn
Lupovitch who headed the Constitution Committee. After three
years of effort the Council fin-

ally finished the revision of its
constitution and after much publicity, special meetings, and letters, placed it before the student
body. The Referendum was passed by a vote of 517 to 101.
The Council has taken under
concerned consideration the badly neglected area of student conduct and responsibility. A permanent Gentleman's Code Committee was established with Iry
Sekulow as chairman. This Committee, using the Gentleman's
Code as a basic premise, introduced to the Council a series of
resolutions, and then, with a
special meeting of activity 'heads'
and with a careful explanation in
the News-Letter, attempted to
call attention- to.the student body
of those areas where students and
student organizations were not
assuming sufficient responsibility.
In dealing with the SAC, the
Council passed a rule and set up
a procedure giving the Student
Council the right to approve any
action taken by the SAC. In an
effort to aid the SAC and a group
of students known as the Central Publicity Office (CPO), the
Council has formed a temporary
Central Publicity Committee to
give official recognition to these
students until they become an
established organization.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JAN. 18, 1957

Unification Or Frustration? ChangeIn Rushing Unlikely
Views Vary On Pledging
(Continued from Page G)
"It is too time-consuming; it
sticks in the back of your mind
all the time, and distracts you
constantly. The old method of
initiation (evidently he means
the paddle-type initiation.—ed.)
was better; once it was over,
there was nothing else to worry
about." "I think it's for the
birds." "It's no good; I have to
study, and it keeps everything in
an uproar." One pledge thought
the practice wasn't so bad; but
when asked whether he had ever
been kidnapped, he replied that
his fraternity had agreed not to
kidnap anyone. He sounded regretful. He added that all the
pledges did instead was scrub
floors and clean the frat house.
"It would be exciting," he remarked wistfully.
Unification Cited
The actives, as might be expected, told a different story. "It
unifies the pledges," was the
most frequent remark. One actives
thought a bit after being asked,
and then said, 'It keeps the
pledges on their toes." Only one
dissenting voice was raised. "I
think it's no good; it's not constructive ... (one fraternity) has
its pledges go down to the hospital and scrub the floors for a
week. That's constructive. Most
actives said that the pledges, or
at least most of them, knew about
kidnapping and initiation practices before they joined. This
statement was verified by a number of pledges.
Perhaps by far the most constructive suggestion heard was
from a graduate student. He
thought that it would be better
to move all the fraternity pledges '
to one part of the dormitory, or I
at least put them all on the first
floor of the Residences where
they could be kidnapped in relative quiet.

Further details are available from the ETS, 20 Nassau
Street, Princeton, New Jersey.
Completed
applications must
reach the ETS office by April 27
and October 15, respectively for
the May 11 and October 29 administrations.

CLAY

John Gassner, Sterling Professor of Playwriting at Yale University, will speak on "The Possibilities and Perils of Modern
Tragedy" in the Amos Taylor,
Jr. Lecture series sponsored by
the Johns Hopkins Playshop,
Sunday, at 8:30 in the Clipper
Room of Shriver Hall. Admission price is sixty cents, and
tickets may be reserved at the
English and Drama Department.
Mr. Gassner has been an editorial advisor for several theatre
journals a professor at Queens
College, N.Y., a critic for publications, and once headed the
script department of the Theatre
Guild of New York. He has
adapted several plays for the
stage, is a member of the Drama
Critics' Circle, and is vice-president of the Shaw Society of
London.
The Playshop's next performance will be George Bernard
Shaw's "Mr.s. Warren's Profession.' Dr. Fagin, director of the
Playshop, said this was one nf
the "most controversial and daring of the British playwright's
comedies." It will be given at
8.30 p.m. in the Barn, on February 21, 22, 23, 28 and again
on March 1 and 2. The last play
of the Playshop will be "Easter,"
by August Strindberg, on April
4, 5, 6, and 11, 12, and 13.

Claire lIruska (left) discusses progress of a new telephone building with the contractor.

- What's a civil engineer's job
in the telephone company?
Claire IIruska graduated in 1953 from
the University of Washington with a B.S.
in Civil Engineering. Today he's with
The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph
Company.
"I 'supervise construction at every
stage," Claire says. "Every telephone
building is designed around the equipment that will be in it. When a building
is needed, I work closely with the architect to make sure his plans fit the needs.
Then I check the contractors' bids. When
the contract is let, it's my responsibility

to see that the builder sticks to the plans
in detail.
"Right now I'm handling the construction of several telephone exchanges, a
large office building in downtown Seattle,
and additions to other .buildings. It's
satisfying work, because I'm on my own a
lot, and getting the jobs done is up to me.
"I've got a career that offers big assignments and responsibilities, and real
opportunities to get ahead in a business
that's growing rapidly. That's what I
was looking for."

Claire Hruska is typical of the many young men
who are finding rewarding careers in the Bell Telephone System. For more information on career

Bell Telephone Laboratories, Western Electric and
Sandia Corporation, see your placement officer.

Put Him Where He Belongs
To some extent, by publishing-,the story on the charges
Senator McCarthy .directed at Dr'. Milton Eisenhower we
are doing precisely what the Senator would want us to
do—we are further publicizing his activity.
McCarthy represents the peculiar anomaly of a man
who has gained his ends largely through the offices of
those who often were bitterly opposed to his tactics. That
is, because his actions were news, they were widely publicized and as a consequence a large proportion of the
American population became McCarthy-conscious. It now
appears that McCarthy is making a feeble effort to reenter the political picture little hindered by the stigma
of senate censure. We are not suggesting that McCarthy is
staging—to borrow a Hollywood term—a comeback or
that he has any chance of ever becoming as important a
political issue as he once was.

Kidnapping:A Disillusionment?
The typical pledge's first conception of his fraternity is one
of a neat, white-shirt-and-tieand-sharp-blue-suit, party-everyweekend organization run by impeccably dressed, smiling actives
whose only purpose in life, seemingly, is to make the gasping
neophytes happy. Unfortunately,
this dream is not allowed to remain extant very long. Tests, demerits, long and dirty cleaning
jobs, endless numbers to be
memorized perfectly, and a general reversion to normal character of the actives manage to
shatter the ideals of nearly all
the pledges. But the final dis-

illusionment comes when the
room of the pledge is invaded,
the hapless pledge himself seized
and dragged to a waiting car,
and taken far, sometimes many
miles, from the city, to return
as best he can.
Most actives agree that the
general idea behind kidnapping
is to try to solidify the pledge
class by subjecting them all to
the same treatment. Another
reason given is that it helps "put
the pledges in their place," inferring that the customary "snow
job" given the pledges before
they join is all too effective. This
purpose, of giving the pledges a

Strong Opinions
Independents, though theoretically unconcerned with the
situation, have expressed strong
opinions on the subject. "How
can we overlook it, when a bunch
of guys comes busting into the
house and tearing it apart? A
lot of them don't even live on
campus;" or,"I don't really care,
since it's none of my business;
but I think it sort of upsets the
dorm." "I wish they would kidnap them quietly; I have studying to do." These were some of
the comments from Independents who ventured an opinion
about the matter. The general
consensus was that kidnapping
was upsetting to all the students
near the scene of action, though
some claimed that they were able
to successfully ignore the Phenomenon.
The pledges interviewed seemed, on the whole, to agree with
the Independents, though the
Opinions expressed were milder.

NEWS -LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JAN. 18, 1957

PAGE NINE

Student Council President Sank Evaluates Semester;
Advising, Orientation On Agenda For Second Term
The following report is, in the
Opinion of President Lew Sank,
the present status of the Council
and a critique of the major ativities undertaken by the Council for the first semester of this
academic year.
In the past few months the
Student Council has taken great
strides in attaining its rightful
Place as the senior governing
body on the Hopkins' Campus.
Regaining much of its lost prestige, it has made serious efforts
to fulfill the objectives as stated
in the newly revised Student
Council Constitution.
In order to improve to any
great extent, however, the Council must direct criticism in two
Major areas. One area concerns
Council representatives who have
the attitude that, having once
been elected by 'popularity contest' to the Council, they no longer feel obligated to devote an
adequate amount of time and
energy to the Council.
This attitude is dissolving as
the Council takes on more work.
It should also be pointed out that
as the committee chairmen aslime more responsibility, and as

each Council member shows more
initiative, the better the status
of the Council. (To this end,
Freshmen Council members have
assigned responsibilities.)
The second, and most important, area of concern is the Council's lack of support from the
students whom they are supposed
to represent, and from the faculty and Administration as well.
Although valid, this point too
long has been depicted as a general Hopkins' trait to be argued
here. Nevertheless, if the Student
Council is to act as a responsible,
representative body, it must have
a greater amount of support from
the campus.
In my estimation, the Student
Council has at least taken those
preliminary steps to deserve increased support. In the weeks to
come, besides the present activities of the Council, I hope to investigate the advising system and
the orientation program given to
freshmen.
Intermediary Position
The Council has made greater
efforts to serve as an intermediary between Administration, faculty, and students. Letters and

special meetings between Council
representatives and administrative and faculty members have
served to represent student opinion and provide a liason between
the undergraduate body and the
Director of Student Activities, Dr.
W. Kelso Morrill; the President's
Office; the Public Relations Office; the Admissions Office; the
Registrar; the Plant Manager's
Office; and Dean Shaffer.
The Executive Committee has
met twice this semester to discuss general Council policy, and
under the direction of the Vice
President, Penn Lupovich, to direct comlnittee action with the
chairman of each permanent
committee of the Council.
Efficient Committees
The Elections Committee under
the Chairmanship of Tom Gibson has done a very efficient job
in conducting the election procedure for Freshman Officers and
for the Referendum on the revised Student Council Constitution. (In the previous two elections, the Council was faced with
contested results and, hence, had
to run re-elections.)
T h e Assembly Committee
boasts a very active program.

Bob Baensch, Chairman, has
worked hard to conduct the five
assemblies which have already
been presented. They are: (1) An
Address by President Milton S.
Eisenhower, (2) The film, "Our
Mister Sun," (3) An Address by
Richard Niebuhr co-sponsored
with the Y.M.C.A. and the Council of Religious Groups, (4) The
Annual Christmas Assembly, and
(5) The Hungarian Relief Rally,
which was also supported by
other campus organizations.
One of the most active committees this year has been the
Public Relations Committee. Paul
Gordon, the original Chairman,
has worked in close cooperation
with the Admissions office in
conducting a series of 'Introduction to College Life' programs
with many local high schools.
This committee has helped conduct the various tours of the
Hopkins campus for visitors. .
The Council has also acted as
host during the President's teas,
where it introduced faculty
guests to the receiving lines.
Tony Salem is the present chairman of the Committee.
Lupovitch Lauded
One of the biggest jobs of this
year's Council was done by Penn
Lupovitch who headed the Constitution Committee. After three
years of effort the Council fin-

ally finished the revision of its
constitution and after much publicity, special meetings, and letters, placed it before the student
body. The Referendum was passed by a vote of 517 to 101.
The Council has taken under
concerned consideration the badly neglected area of student conduct and responsibility. A permanent Gentleman's Code Committee was established with Iry
Sekulow as chairman. This Committee, using the Gentleman's
Code as a basic premise, introduced to the Council a series of
resolutions, and then, with a
special meeting of activity 'heads'
and with a careful explanation in
the News-Letter, attempted to
call attention- to.the student body
of those areas where students and
student organizations were not
assuming sufficient responsibility.
In dealing with the SAC, the
Council passed a rule and set up
a procedure giving the Student
Council the right to approve any
action taken by the SAC. In an
effort to aid the SAC and a group
of students known as the Central Publicity Office (CPO), the
Council has formed a temporary
Central Publicity Committee to
give official recognition to these
students until they become an
established organization.

NEWS-LETTER

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, JAN. 18, 1957

Unification Or Frustration? ChangeIn Rushing Unlikely
Views Vary On Pledging
(Continued from Page G)
"It is too time-consuming; it
sticks in the back of your mind
all the time, and distracts you
constantly. The old method of
initiation (evidently he means
the paddle-type initiation.—ed.)
was better; once it was over,
there was nothing else to worry
about." "I think it's for the
birds." "It's no good; I have to
study, and it keeps everything in
an uproar." One pledge thought
the practice wasn't so bad; but
when asked whether he had ever
been kidnapped, he replied that
his fraternity had agreed not to
kidnap anyone. He sounded regretful. He added that all the
pledges did instead was scrub
floors and clean the frat house.
"It would be exciting," he remarked wistfully.
Unification Cited
The actives, as might be expected, told a different story. "It
unifies the pledges," was the
most frequent remark. One actives
thought a bit after being asked,
and then said, 'It keeps the
pledges on their toes." Only one
dissenting voice was raised. "I
think it's no good; it's not constructive ... (one fraternity) has
its pledges go down to the hospital and scrub the floors for a
week. That's constructive. Most
actives said that the pledges, or
at least most of them, knew about
kidnapping and initiation practices before they joined. This
statement was verified by a number of pledges.
Perhaps by far the most constructive suggestion heard was
from a graduate student. He
thought that it would be better
to move all the fraternity pledges '
to one part of the dormitory, or I
at least put them all on the first
floor of the Residences where
they could be kidnapped in relative quiet.

For Med School
Candidates for admission to
medical schools in the fall of
1958 are advised to take the Medical College Admission Test in
May, it was announced by the
Educational Testing Society.
Further details are available from the ETS, 20 Nassau
Street, Princeton, New Jersey.
Completed
applications must
reach the ETS office by April 27
and October 15, respectively for
the May 11 and October 29 administrations.
